The file ./README.md has been updated. Here's the result of running `cat -n` on a snippet of the edited file:
   128â†’1. Open `index.html` in your favorite editor
   129â†’2. Make your changes
   130â†’3. Refresh your browser to see updates (or use live reload with a local server)
   131â†’
   132â†’**No build step, no bundlers, no transpilationâ€”just edit and refresh!**
   133â†’
   134â†’---
   135â†’
   136â†’## Deployment
   137â†’
   138â†’This site is automatically deployed to **GitHub Pages** via a **GitHub Actions** CI/CD pipeline. Every push to the `main` branch triggers a new deployment, ensuring the live site is always up to date.
   139â†’
   140â†’### How It Works
   141â†’
   142â†’The deployment process uses the [`.github/workflows/deploy.yml`](.github/workflows/deploy.yml) workflow, which consists of two main jobs:
   143â†’
   144â†’#### 1. Build Job
   145â†’
   146â†’```yaml
   147â†’- Checkout code from repository
   148â†’- Set up Node.js environment (v20)
   149â†’- Install dependencies (npm ci)
   150â†’- Build the project (npm run build)
   151â†’- Upload build artifacts to GitHub Pages
   152â†’```
   153â†’
   154â†’The build job runs on `ubuntu-latest` and prepares the static site for deployment by:
   155â†’- Installing all npm dependencies from `package-lock.json`
   156â†’- Running the build script to generate production-ready files in the `./dist` directory
   157â†’- Uploading the `./dist` folder as a Pages artifact
   158â†’
   159â†’#### 2. Deploy Job
   160â†’
   161â†’```yaml
   162â†’- Deploy the uploaded artifact to GitHub Pages
   163â†’- Output the deployment URL
   164â†’```
   165â†’
   166â†’The deploy job waits for the build job to complete (`needs: build`) and then publishes the artifact to GitHub Pages using the official `actions/deploy-pages@v4` action.
   167â†’
   168â†’### Deployment Triggers
   169â†’
   170â†’The workflow automatically runs when:
   171â†’
   172â†’- **Push to `main`** - Any commit pushed to the main branch triggers a deployment
   173â†’- **Manual trigger** - Can be manually triggered via the GitHub Actions UI (`workflow_dispatch`)
   174â†’
   175â†’### Custom Domain Configuration
   176â†’
   177â†’The site is accessible via the custom domain **[abediaz.ai](https://abediaz.ai)**, configured through:
   178â†’
   179â†’1. **CNAME File** - The [`CNAME`](CNAME) file in the repository root contains `abediaz.ai`, which tells GitHub Pages to serve the site at this custom domain
   180â†’2. **DNS Configuration** - The domain registrar's DNS is configured with:
   181â†’   - An `A` record (or `ALIAS`/`ANAME`) pointing to GitHub Pages' IP addresses
   182â†’   - Or a `CNAME` record pointing to `<username>.github.io`
   183â†’
   184â†’This combination ensures visitors can access the site at the professional branded domain rather than the default `*.github.io` URL.
   185â†’
   186â†’### Deployment Permissions
   187â†’
   188â†’The workflow requires specific permissions to deploy to GitHub Pages:
   189â†’
   190â†’```yaml
   191â†’permissions:
   192â†’  contents: read    # Read repository contents
   193â†’  pages: write      # Deploy to GitHub Pages
   194â†’  id-token: write   # Verify deployment identity
   195â†’```
   196â†’
   197â†’These permissions follow the principle of least privilege, granting only what's necessary for the deployment process.
   198â†’
   199â†’### Concurrency Control
   200â†’
   201â†’To prevent conflicts, the workflow uses concurrency control:
   202â†’
   203â†’```yaml
   204â†’concurrency:
   205â†’  group: "pages"
   206â†’  cancel-in-progress: true
   207â†’```
   208â†’
   209â†’This ensures that if multiple deployments are triggered simultaneously, only the most recent one proceeds, canceling any in-progress deployments to avoid race conditions.
   210â†’
   211â†’### Monitoring Deployments
   212â†’
   213â†’You can monitor deployment status:
   214â†’
   215â†’- **GitHub Actions Tab** - View real-time logs and deployment history at `https://github.com/<username>/abediaz.ai/actions`
   216â†’- **Environments Tab** - Check the `github-pages` environment for deployment URLs and status
   217â†’- **Commit Status** - Each commit shows a green checkmark (âœ“) when deployment succeeds
   218â†’
   219â†’### Manual Deployment
   220â†’
   221â†’To manually trigger a deployment without pushing code:
   222â†’
   223â†’1. Go to the **Actions** tab in the GitHub repository
   224â†’2. Select the **"Deploy to GitHub Pages"** workflow
   225â†’3. Click **"Run workflow"** and select the `main` branch
   226â†’4. Click the green **"Run workflow"** button
   227â†’
   228â†’This is useful for redeploying after configuration changes or troubleshooting deployment issues.
   229â†’
   230â†’---
   231â†’
   232â†’## Overview
   233â†’
   234â†’This is the personal portfolio website for **Abe Diaz**, a passionate technologist and Sr. Technical Program Manager on the Disaster Relief by Amazon team. The site serves as a professional online presence showcasing technical expertise, leadership experience, and personal interests.
   235â†’
   236â†’**Purpose:** This portfolio targets recruiters and hiring managers at leading AI companies including Anthropic, OpenAI, and DeepMind, demonstrating both technical capabilities and attention to detail through clean, purposeful design and implementation.

    10â†’## Tech Stack
    11â†’
    12â†’This portfolio is intentionally minimalist, prioritizing **performance**, **maintainability**, and **simplicity** over framework complexity.
    13â†’
    14â†’### Core Technologies
    15â†’
    16â†’- **Static HTML/CSS** - Single-file architecture (`index.html`) with inline CSS for zero build overhead and maximum performance
    17â†’- **Oswald Google Font** - Bold, modern typeface from Google Fonts for heading typography
    18â†’- **Responsive Design** - Mobile-first CSS with media queries supporting desktop (768px+), tablet, and mobile (480px, 360px) breakpoints
    19â†’- **CSS Custom Properties** - Design system variables for colors, typography, spacing, and layout consistency
    20â†’- **Semantic HTML5** - Accessible markup with proper meta tags, Open Graph, and Twitter Card support
    21â†’
    22â†’### Deployment & Infrastructure
    23â†’
    24â†’- **GitHub Pages** - Static site hosting with custom domain support
    25â†’- **GitHub Actions** - Automated CI/CD pipeline that builds and deploys on every push to `main`
    26â†’- **Custom Domain** - Professional branding via `abediaz.ai` with DNS configuration through CNAME
    27â†’
    28â†’### Design Philosophy
    29â†’
    30â†’**Why static HTML?**
    31â†’- âš¡ **Performance** - Near-instant page loads with no JavaScript framework overhead
    32â†’- ğŸ”’ **Security** - Minimal attack surface with no backend or database
    33â†’- ğŸ’° **Cost** - Free hosting via GitHub Pages
    34â†’- ğŸ› ï¸ **Simplicity** - Easy to maintain, update, and understand
    35â†’- â™¿ **Accessibility** - Works everywhere, including low-bandwidth connections and assistive technologies
    36â†’
    37â†’This architecture demonstrates that not every project needs a complex frameworkâ€”sometimes the simplest solution is the best solution.
    38â†’
    39â†’---
    40â†’
    41â†’## Local Development
    42â†’
    43â†’Since this is a **static HTML site** with no build process, getting started is remarkably simple. No Node.js, npm, or build tools required!
    44â†’
    45â†’### Prerequisites
    46â†’
    47â†’- **Modern web browser** (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
    48â†’- **Git** (for cloning the repository)
    49â†’- *(Optional)* **Local web server** for advanced testing
    50â†’
    51â†’### Clone the Repository
    52â†’
    53â†’```bash
    54â†’# Clone via HTTPS
    55â†’git clone https://github.com/abediaz/abediaz.ai.git
    56â†’
    57â†’# Or clone via SSH
    58â†’git clone git@github.com:abediaz/abediaz.ai.git

    63â†’
    64â†’### Running Locally
    65â†’
    66â†’You have multiple options for viewing the site locally:
    67â†’
    68â†’#### Option 1: Direct File Access (Simplest)
    69â†’
    70â†’Simply open `index.html` in your browser:
    71â†’
    72â†’```bash
    73â†’# macOS
    74â†’open index.html
    75â†’
    76â†’# Linux
    77â†’xdg-open index.html
    78â†’
    79â†’# Windows
    80â†’start index.html
    81â†’```
    82â†’
    83â†’Or double-click `index.html` in your file explorer.
    84â†’
    85â†’**Note:** This method works perfectly for this static site, but some advanced features (like service workers or certain CORS-restricted resources) may require a local server.
    86â†’
    87â†’#### Option 2: Python HTTP Server
    88â†’
    89â†’If you have Python installed (most macOS/Linux systems do by default):
    90â†’
    91â†’```bash
    92â†’# Python 3
    93â†’python -m http.server 8000
    94â†’
    95â†’# Python 2
    96â†’python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8000
    97â†’```
    98â†’
    99â†’Then visit: [http://localhost:8000](http://localhost:8000)
   100â†’
   101â†’#### Option 3: Node.js HTTP Server
   102â†’
   103â†’If you have Node.js installed:
   104â†’
   105â†’```bash
   106â†’# Using npx (no installation required)

   115â†’
   116â†’#### Option 4: VS Code Live Server
   117â†’
   118â†’If you use Visual Studio Code:
   119â†’
   120â†’1. Install the "Live Server" extension by Ritwick Dey
   121â†’2. Right-click `index.html` and select "Open with Live Server"
   122â†’3. The site will open automatically in your browser with live reload
   123â†’
   124â†’### Making Changes
   125â†’
   126â†’Since all code is in `index.html` with inline CSS, you can edit directly:
   127â†’
   128â†’1. Open `index.html` in your favorite editor
   129â†’2. Make your changes
   130â†’3. Refresh your browser to see updates (or use live reload with a local server)
   131â†’
   132â†’**No build step, no bundlers, no transpilationâ€”just edit and refresh!**
   133â†’
   134â†’---
   135â†’
   136â†’## Deployment
   137â†’
   138â†’This site is automatically deployed to **GitHub Pages** via a **GitHub Actions** CI/CD pipeline. Every push to the `main` branch triggers a new deployment, ensuring the live site is always up to date.
   139â†’
   140â†’### How It Works
   141â†’
   142â†’The deployment process uses the [`.github/workflows/deploy.yml`](.github/workflows/deploy.yml) workflow, which consists of two main jobs:
   143â†’
   144â†’#### 1. Build Job
   145â†’
   146â†’```yaml
   147â†’- Checkout code from repository
   148â†’- Set up Node.js environment (v20)
   149â†’- Install dependencies (npm ci)
   150â†’- Build the project (npm run build)
   151â†’- Upload build artifacts to GitHub Pages
   152â†’```
   153â†’
   154â†’The build job runs on `ubuntu-latest` and prepares the static site for deployment by:
   155â†’- Installing all npm dependencies from `package-lock.json`
   156â†’- Running the build script to generate production-ready files in the `./dist` directory
   157â†’- Uploading the `./dist` folder as a Pages artifact
   158â†’
   159â†’#### 2. Deploy Job
   160â†’
   161â†’```yaml
   162â†’- Deploy the uploaded artifact to GitHub Pages
   163â†’- Output the deployment URL
   164â†’```
   165â†’
   166â†’The deploy job waits for the build job to complete (`needs: build`) and then publishes the artifact to GitHub Pages using the official `actions/deploy-pages@v4` action.
   167â†’
   168â†’### Deployment Triggers
   169â†’
   170â†’The workflow automatically runs when:
   171â†’
   172â†’- **Push to `main`** - Any commit pushed to the main branch triggers a deployment
   173â†’- **Manual trigger** - Can be manually triggered via the GitHub Actions UI (`workflow_dispatch`)
   174â†’
   175â†’### Custom Domain Configuration
   176â†’
   177â†’The site is accessible via the custom domain **[abediaz.ai](https://abediaz.ai)**, configured through:
   178â†’
   179â†’1. **CNAME File** - The [`CNAME`](CNAME) file in the repository root contains `abediaz.ai`, which tells GitHub Pages to serve the site at this custom domain
   180â†’2. **DNS Configuration** - The domain registrar's DNS is configured with:
   181â†’   - An `A` record (or `ALIAS`/`ANAME`) pointing to GitHub Pages' IP addresses
   182â†’   - Or a `CNAME` record pointing to `<username>.github.io`
   183â†’
   184â†’This combination ensures visitors can access the site at the professional branded domain rather than the default `*.github.io` URL.
   185â†’
   186â†’### Deployment Permissions
   187â†’
   188â†’The workflow requires specific permissions to deploy to GitHub Pages:
   189â†’
   190â†’```yaml
   191â†’permissions:
   192â†’  contents: read    # Read repository contents
   193â†’  pages: write      # Deploy to GitHub Pages
   194â†’  id-token: write   # Verify deployment identity
   195â†’```
   196â†’
   197â†’These permissions follow the principle of least privilege, granting only what's necessary for the deployment process.
   198â†’
   199â†’### Concurrency Control
   200â†’
   201â†’To prevent conflicts, the workflow uses concurrency control:
   202â†’
   203â†’```yaml
   204â†’concurrency:
   205â†’  group: "pages"
   206â†’  cancel-in-progress: true
   207â†’```
   208â†’
   209â†’This ensures that if multiple deployments are triggered simultaneously, only the most recent one proceeds, canceling any in-progress deployments to avoid race conditions.
   210â†’
   211â†’### Monitoring Deployments
   212â†’
   213â†’You can monitor deployment status:
   214â†’

   216â†’- **Environments Tab** - Check the `github-pages` environment for deployment URLs and status
   217â†’- **Commit Status** - Each commit shows a green checkmark (âœ“) when deployment succeeds
   218â†’
   219â†’### Manual Deployment
   220â†’
   221â†’To manually trigger a deployment without pushing code:
   222â†’
   223â†’1. Go to the **Actions** tab in the GitHub repository
   224â†’2. Select the **"Deploy to GitHub Pages"** workflow
   225â†’3. Click **"Run workflow"** and select the `main` branch
   226â†’4. Click the green **"Run workflow"** button
   227â†’
   228â†’This is useful for redeploying after configuration changes or troubleshooting deployment issues.

   234â†’This is the personal portfolio website for **Abe Diaz**, a passionate technologist and Sr. Technical Program Manager on the Disaster Relief by Amazon team. The site serves as a professional online presence showcasing technical expertise, leadership experience, and personal interests.
